    def find_available_port(
        custom_host: Optional[str] = None,
        custom_range: Optional[range] = None,
        will_close_then_reopen_socket: bool = False,
    ) -> Tuple[str, int, socket.socket]:
        """
        The default and recommended approach here is to return a bound socket to the
        caller, requiring the caller to keep the socket-object alive as long as the
        port is needed.
    
        If the caller for some reason closes the returned socket there is no guarantee
        that it can bind again to the same port for two reasons:
        1) the underlying socket can be in TIME_WAIT meaning that it is closed
        but port is not ready to be re-bound yet, and 2) some other process managed to
        bind the port before the original caller gets around to re-bind.
    
        Thus, we expect clients calling find_available_port() to keep the returned
        socket-object alive and open as long as the port is needed. If a socket-object
        is passed to other modules like for example a websocket-server, use dup() to
        obtain a new Python socket-object bound to the same underlying socket (and hence
        the same port). That way, even if the other module closes its given socket-
        object, the port is still reserved and bound by the original socket-object.
    
        See e.g. implementation and comments in EvaluatorServerConfig
    
        However, our PrefectEnsemble integrates with Dask and DaskScheduler which only
        accepts an integer port-argument, not a bound socket-object or even a port-range.
        For this reason it is believed that we must allow the close-and-rebind  -pattern,
        i.e. the SO_REUSEADDR flag may have to be set before binding the socket. If
        the client really wants this behaviour, specify the argument
    
            will_close_then_reopen_socket = true
    
        in the call, but be aware that issue (2) above becomes a lot more likely.
        Additionally, quite some unexpected behaviour is going on when this flag is used,
        as demonstrated in test_port_handler.py. In particular, it looks like on Linux,
        a port can be re-bound even if there is already a live socket bound to it.
    
        So use this flag with extreme caution and only when in the hour of utmost need!
        Ideally it should be removed.
        """
        current_host = custom_host if custom_host is not None else _get_ip_address()
        current_range = (
            custom_range if custom_range is not None else range(51820, 51840 + 1)
        )
    
        if current_range.start == current_range.stop:
            ports = list(range(current_range.start, current_range.stop + 1))
        else:
            ports = list(range(current_range.start, current_range.stop))
    
        random.shuffle(ports)
        for port in ports:
            try:
                return (
                    current_host,
                    port,
                    _bind_socket(
                        host=current_host,
                        port=port,
                        will_close_then_reopen_socket=will_close_then_reopen_socket,
                    ),
                )
            except PortAlreadyInUseException:
                continue

title: Clean build.yml once Shapely adds wheel *macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl on PyPi
body:
Python 3.10 testing is being added to the GitHub Actions workflow in PR #2834 
However, library Shapely, which xtgeo imports and use, at the moment does not provide wheel *macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl, for details see [issue](https://github.com/shapely/shapely/issues/1348).
Therefore, command `brew install geos` was added to `build.yml` for Shapely to work correctly. This lines needs to be cleaned up once the wheel *macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl for Shapely library is distributed through PyPi https://pypi.org/project/Shapely/#description

title: Next iteration does not immediately start after jobs were killed due to MAX_RUNTIME
body:
**Describe the bug**
A user reports that MAX_RUNTIME is not enforced, but the logs says it is actually enforced, but that time increases in the GUI so as to give the appearance that it's not. This is also seemingly blocking the next iteration from starting.

The former is probably caused by the latter.

User had 4h MAX_RUNTIME, next iteration started after 7h.

**To Reproduce**
TBD

**Expected behavior**
When jobs are killed, the timer should stop. Next iteration should start.

**Enviromment**
 - OS: RHEL7
 - ERT/Komodo Release: stable
 - Python version: 3.6
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: yes

>
> I have a model that I'm attempting to run, but I'm running into the same error past a certain number of realizations (somewhere between 1000-2000). The error makes me me think that I'm overflowing an int somewhere, but I'm not sure exactly how the error message is calculating realizations (I don't have anywhere near 32523 in the example below). 
>
> Could anyone offer some insight on this issue? It seems like I'm running into a limit, but I'm not sure if I can restructure something or if I can at least assess what limit Im'm hitting.

#0    Object "/prog/res/komodo/2022.02.04-py36-rhel7/root/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/ecl/.libs/libecl.so", at 0x7f0c22924cae, in util_abort__
```

This also happened with index 32737 and 32626 as well. 

The error originates from this function: 

https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/e4ec2b1b1534ce89c4703c718ab3e94a3221ca33/libres/lib/enkf/state_map.cpp#L145-L156

The function `int_vector_safe_iget` returns a default value (1=STATE_UNDEFINED) if the index is out of bounds, so the problem is most likely that the index is to large, and not that the state transition is incorrect. We should try to figure out where this is coming from. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Unknown

**Expected behavior**
No crash

**Enviromment**
 - OS: RHEL7
 - ERT/Komodo Release: 2022.02.04
 - Python version: 3.6
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: [yes|no]

**Additional context**
Link to logs can be obtained by contacting @sondreso

body:
**Issue**
Resolves #2794 and #3015


**Approach**
Ensemble objects already have an API for stating whether each individual realization is active or not. In this PR, realizations marked as inactive are skipped when sending jobs to the Prefect executor.

Adding labels helps the maintainers when writing release notes, see sections and the
corresponding labels here: https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/main/.github/release.yml

title: Total realizations of phase calculated wrongly in `EvaluatorTracker._progress()`
body: **Describe the bug** In calculating `EvaluatorTracker` `_progress()` we have: https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/daf755166a0428d35550fb85c64df53ff30289ea/ert_shared/status/utils.py#L43 Here total realizations is calculated wrongly, as https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/daf755166a0428d35550fb85c64df53ff30289ea/ert_shared/status/tracker/evaluator.py#L144 is populated iteratively along with events being yielded from `track()`, which is the actual progress we seek to measure. **To Reproduce** Change `status` of snapshot to `REALIZATION_STATE_FINISHED` in https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/daf755166a0428d35550fb85c64df53ff30289ea/tests/ert_tests/status/test_evaluator_tracker.py#L24 and print `tracker._progress()` inside of https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/daf755166a0428d35550fb85c64df53ff30289ea/tests/ert_tests/status/test_evaluator_tracker.py#L294-L295 and run the test with flag `-s`. Then watch progress going to `1.0` immediately. This is because total realizations are calculated wrongly, but equal to the current number of realizations completed. **Expected behavior** Progress is calculated properly for realizations, by correctly calculating the total number of realizations for some phase. **Screenshots** **Environment** - ERT 2.34

title: Flakyness in dark_storage tests
body:
A new test added in #2704, would not pass, as tests would arbitrarily fail with empty data in some instances. 

Managed to create another version of the tests that did pass, in #3051 

Did not figure out what was the cause, but suspect some initalization/cleanup code in dark_storage. It probably happens because the performace tests run the methods many times to calculate average times, which then increases the likelihood of the error occurring.

I have downloaded the tmp files of the test runs, and the data looks like it should, so the error seems to be in the loading of the data.

Running semeio/tests/jobs/test_scale_observations/test_scale_observations.py, for example [here](https://github.com/equinor/semeio/blob/1e4a9924d6c03442903ba9d878dc374e89d32d77/tests/jobs/test_scale_observations/test_scale_observations.py#L15).

will some times segfault, relevant stack trace:
```
  File "/path/to/site-packages/cwrap/prototype.py", line 218 in __call__
  File "/path/to/site-packages/res/enkf/enkf_main.py", line 313 in free
  File "/path/to/site-packages/cwrap/basecclass.py", line 137 in __del__
```

and:

```
  File "/path/to/site-packages/res/enkf/ert_workflow_list.py", line 67 in __init__
  File "/path/to/site-packages/res/enkf/res_config.py", line 177 in _alloc_from_content
  File "/path/to/site-packages/res/enkf/res_config.py", line 111 in __init__
  File "/path/to/semeio/test-root/tests/jobs/conftest.py", line 27 in setup_ert
```
also seen for the triggering factor:

```
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/shutil.py", line 348 in copytree
  File "/path/to/semeio/test-root/tests/jobs/conftest.py", line 24 in setup_ert
```


the triggering part seems to be more coincidental, as I have seen different traces. `enkf_main.py`, `free` has been shared in all instances. The earliest `ert` tag I can find with this behavior seems to be: 2.33.0-rc1.

title: test_def_active_close_linux_nok_nok fails
body:
I get _ConnectionRefusedError: [Errno 111] Connection refused_ in `test_port_handler.py:: _simulate_server()`

https://github.com/equinor/ert/runs/5338174201?check_suite_focus=true

This indicates that the dummy-server did not start before the client tries to connect. Should fix this with some barrier, e.g. like ready_event / start_event here

https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/48891dafa4c2ff144f66d629f48149f4281c7577/tests/ert_tests/services/test_base_service.py#L225-L244

title: Improve failure behaviour from ert client to storage
body:
**Issue**
Resolves #2953 


**Approach**
The console already has functionality for removing the `.ert` directory, but only if it catches a TimeoutError. The storage initialization raises a RuntimeError. I chose to change the exception raised instead of catching one  more exception.

https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/main/ert3/console/_console.py#L223-L229

## Pre review checklist

Adding labels helps the maintainers when writing release notes, see sections and the
corresponding labels here: https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/main/.github/release.yml

title: When workflow job fails the workflow as a whole still succeeds
body:
**Describe the bug**
In the test: https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/main/tests/libres_tests/res/enkf/test_row_scaling_case.py#L206 the only workflow job fails in current master[1], however the workflow as a whole is registered as passing and since the test itself does not really verify the results the test as a whole also succeeds - i.e. we have for some time had a false green test.

As I see it there are two problems here:

1. **Most importantly**: the workflow run code should correctly return `False` when one of the jobs has failed.
2. The test in question should be updated to actually verify the data in some way - then we would have detected this failure when it happened.

title: Fix row scaling local configuration job
body: This PR fixes a bug in a workflow script which has been run in a test of local configuration / row scaling. The fix in this PR is "honest enough". But the real problem is in my opinon #2955 - which has allowed this bug to be under cover since #2645.

title: `ert3 init` leaves directory `.ert` behind when initialization fails
body:
**Describe the bug**
If an ert3 workspace is attempted initialized, but connection with the storage server fails, the directory `.ert` is still created and rerunning `ert3 init` (after storage is started) will not work until the directory is manually removed.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. terminal A: `ert3 init`. Results possibly in `RuntimeError: Server started, but none of the URLs provided worked` when it has tried using URL from an outdated `storage_server.json`.
2. terminal B: `ert3 service start storage` (and ensure the wrong `storage_server.json` is overwritten or overridden)
3. terminal A: `ert3 init`. Results in `Already inside an ERT workspace, found /work/projects/ert/ert3_examples/polynomial/.ert`

**Expected behavior**
Successful initialization in step 3.

title: Possible void return
body:
This code
https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/1645f3ea1699aee1ebbd8219758c574b51aef1ae/libres/lib/analysis/analysis_module.cpp#L72-L77
may return void when a pointer is expected - unsure how Python/CWrap copes with this.

Should probably use one of those smoothers as default, or at least return NULL.

title: Starting multiple ERT with ensemble evaluator will eventually exhaust port range
body:
**Describe the bug**
A user started 9 ERT instances and got an `Address already in use` error from the system.

**To Reproduce**
Start ERT 9 times (on an RGS node)

**Expected behavior**
This should work fine.

**Enviromment**
 - OS: RHEL7
 - ERT/Komodo Release: 2022.01.01
 - Python version: 3.6
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: yes

body:
**Describe the bug**
Failed github action on PR.

https://github.com/equinor/ert/actions/runs/1793572277

`FAILED ert_tests/ensemble_evaluator/test_ensemble_legacy.py::test_run_and_cancel_legacy_ensemble`
```

 =================================== FAILURES ===================================
_____________________ test_run_and_cancel_legacy_ensemble ______________________

tmpdir = local('/private/var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T/pytest-of-runner/pytest-0/test_run_and_cancel_legacy_ens0')
make_ensemble_builder = <function make_ensemble_builder.<locals>._make_ensemble_builder at 0x133ab0a60>

    @pytest.mark.timeout(60)
    def test_run_and_cancel_legacy_ensemble(tmpdir, make_ensemble_builder):
        num_reals = 10
        custom_port_range = range(1024, 65535)
        with tmpdir.as_cwd():
            ensemble = make_ensemble_builder(tmpdir, num_reals, 2, job_sleep=5).build()
            config = EvaluatorServerConfig(custom_port_range=custom_port_range)
    
            evaluator = EnsembleEvaluator(ensemble, config, 0, ee_id="1")
    
            with evaluator.run() as mon:
                cancel = True
                for _ in mon.track():
                    if cancel:
                        mon.signal_cancel()
                        cancel = False
    
>           assert evaluator._ensemble.get_status() == state.ENSEMBLE_STATE_CANCELLED
E           AssertionError: assert 'Stopped' == 'Cancelled'

E             + Stopped

ert_tests/ensemble_evaluator/test_ensemble_legacy.py:52: AssertionError
```

Also logged 

    WARNING  ert_shared.ensemble_evaluator.ensemble.base:base.py:53 Illegal state transition from Cancelled to Stopped

Which is a hint that perhaps this test was always flaky, or that cancelling doesn't work properly.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Push to a PR

**Expected behavior**
Dont fail


**Enviromment**
 - 3.8 macos-latest

title: ERT3 init hits the proxy with on-prem environment setup
body:
**Describe the bug** If `ert3 init` hits the proxy when accessing `127.0.0.1`, then it will get a redirect response that it won't (?) and cannot follow. **To Reproduce** It should be okay to have the environment variable(s) `http_proxy` pointing to a real proxy, but the env variable `no_proxy` should take care the exception for the loopback address. On-prem, in a bash setup, this is a possible environment (not intentionally user-manipulated): ``` [havb@be-lx895926] $ env | grep -i no_proxy NO_PROXY=localhost,127.0.0.1 no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.0/8,::1 ``` That these are not equal, should be regarded as a setup bug. Which of these variables are used, varies by application. Python prefers the lower-case version. Python `requests` library does not support CIDR blocks like `127.0.0.0/8.` With `http_proxy` defined, and `no_proxy` as above, `ert3 init` fails with ``` $ ert3 init Failed to fetch from experiments. Response: Redirection

Redirect

Traceback (most recent call last): [...] raise JSONDecodeError("Expecting value", s, err.value) from None json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0) ``` **Workarounds** `export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1` or add `http://localhost:51820` as the first entry in `storage_server.json`. **Expected behavior** ERT should avoid using the proxy. **Enviromment** - OS: RHEL7 - ERT: 2.32~git - Python version 3.6 - Remote/HPC execution involved: no **Additional context** See https://about.gitlab.com/blog/2021/01/27/we-need-to-talk-no-proxy/

title: Handle memory issues on worker node
body:
**Describe the bug**

title: Do not build vanilla step on unexpected step type
body:
During my work in #2755 I discovered that the step builder will build a vanilla step if the type is neither `unix` nor `function`. I think it should fail instead...

title: PrefectEnsemble does not ignore inactive realizations
body:
**Describe the bug**
When building an ensemble, you have the option of setting realizations to be inactive. However, this is never checked by the `PrefectEnsemble` and it will run all realizations regardless. 

**Expected behavior**
Realizations marked as inactive should not be evaluated.

title: Make AutorunTestEnsemble cancellable
body:
**Issue**
Resolves #2785

**Approach**
In order to prevent flakyness in testing of
run_and_get_successful_realizations, we need to ensure that all events
are sent before the evaluator shuts down. This commits makes the
ensemble cancellable, but does nothing when asked to cancel. This way
all events will be propagated before the evaluator is done, and
run_and_get_successful_realizations proceeds to check the number of
successful realizations.


## Pre review checklist

- [x] Added appropriate labels

Adding labels helps the maintainers when writing release notes, see sections and the
corresponding labels here: https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/main/.github/release.yml

title: Stop using a Client instance over long time spans
body:
**Issue**
Resolves #2756 


**Approach**
If Client's loop doesn't run in <20 second intervals, the WS connection
will time out and #2756 will happen for unix steps running longer than
20 seconds. Hence we make all Client usage single-use.

title: Always handle connection errors when monitoring the ensemble
body:
**Issue**
Resolves #2769


**Approach**
The monitor can experience various connection issues, which will result
in connection closed errors. This commits adds handling of these errors
and will retry the connection.

The handling of ConnectionRefusedError is also changed, and will no
longer throw an exception if encountered. Instead, the ensemble is
cancelled, and the number of successful realizations is reported.
The responsibility of deciding experiment failure/success based on
number of failing realizations is left to the parent scope.

Test are also added to show that the correct number of successful
realizations is reported, even in the event of connection refused and
connection closed errors.

## Pre review checklist

- [x] Added appropriate labels

Adding labels helps the maintainers when writing release notes, see sections and the
corresponding labels here: https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/main/.github/release.yml

title: Expected boolean return from void-function
body:
**Issue**
Possibly resolves #2753

**Approach**
The Python wrapper expected to return a boolean, whereas the C++ -function was void. This is in my experience very likely to cause random crashes at unexpected times, and should in any case be fixed.

title: Long-running unix step will kill fail due to websocket ping timeout
body:
**Describe the bug**
Long-running unix steps will likely make the `ee_client` used to send messages before and after tasks run—die. It will appear as though sending something failed abnormally. What likely happened is that pings from the client to the evaluator server were not sent, and the evaluator server summarily closed the connection. We don't see this exception since we do not capture WS logs.

**To Reproduce**
Run a long-running task in a unix step

**Expected behavior**
`run_until_complete` should ideally be called once, really early in `run` such that all subsequent subroutines are `async`.

**Enviromment**
 - OS: RHEL7
 - ERT/Komodo Release: main
 - Python version: any
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: n/a

title: Data leaks between different workspaces
body:
**Describe the bug**
When running multiple workspaces towards the same storage instance, data from one workspace should not be accessible from the other workspace.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. `pip install ert`
2. `ert3 service start storage`
3. `ert3 init --example polynomial`
4. `cd polynomial`
5. `ert3 run evaluation`
6. `cd ..`
7. `ert3 init --example spe1`
8. `cd spe1`
9. `ert3 run evaluation`

**Current behaviour**
ERT3 will complain that `evaluation` has already been carried out (but that experiment belongs to a different workspace).

**Expected behaviour**
I would expect it to run the SPE1 evaluation experiment without any hassle. Also, afterwards when visualising I would expect only data related to the SPE1 example to be presented.

**Enviromment**
 - OS: RHEL7
 - ERT/Komodo Release: `main`
 - Python version: `3.6`
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: no

title: Remove reuse_addr parameter from port_handler
body:
After some investigation (Thanks to @BjarneHerland and @mortalisk ) it seems like the `reuse_addr=true` in the `port_handler.py ` is the cause of the flakiness in the `ert3/engine/integration/test_engine` tests.

When asked for a socket the port handler returns a socket which the storage server is not able to use causing an exception. If we set `reuse_addr=false` the port handler seems to only return usable sockets. 

It might be a good idea to revisit the code where this parameter is used and examine the consequences of removing it.

title: Investigate potentially changed behaviour on inconsistent time maps
body:
There are indications during debugging of https://github.com/equinor/ert/issues/2546 that the real issue is inconsistent time maps.

The issue is created by running predictions with different report steps for the realisations as discussed in the internal [Wiki](https://wiki.equinor.com/wiki/index.php/Debugging). However, it is now reported that the GUI is hanging instead of closing down as previously.

A good start would be to try to reproduce the `inconsistent time maps` issue and see how ERT behaves now compared to earlier...

title: Fix failure when using pbs driver
body:
**Issue**
Resolves #2687

**Approach**
Move `_on_task_failure` function out of `PrefectEnsemble`

The reference to `self._on_task_failure` caused the entire `PrefectEnsemble`
to be pickled. This is not intended, nor is it safe, in particular
because the Executor might contain thread locks. This commit moves the
`_on_task_failure` function out of the `PrefectEnsemble` object, and rather
binds _only_ the `ee_id` before the task is pickled.


## Pre review checklist

- [x] Added appropriate labels

Adding labels helps the maintainers when writing release notes, see sections and the
corresponding labels here: https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/main/.github/release.yml

title: EnsembleEvaluator Monitor should retry in case of connection failure
body:
**Describe the bug**
Currently the monitor will crash if the `SyncWebsocketDuplexer` is disconnected unexpectedly. While https://github.com/equinor/ert/pull/2528 should reduce the number of failures, we should be tolerant to random network errors that occur. Screenshot includes traceback from user report.

N/A

**Expected behavior**
Monitor should try to reconnect before failing

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3437958/146035043-dc949152-1d9b-4dcd-a41d-6ff9e8073e68.png)

 - ERT/Komodo Release: 2020.11.02
 - Python version: 3.6
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: yes

title: repr(AnalysisIterConfig()) is broken

calling `repr` on `AnalysisIterConfig` fails with `TypeError('%x format: an integer is required, not method') raised in repr()` due to self._adress being a method and not a property:

https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/3f84b979b985376aade9203a6b977b9b541d8c14/res/enkf/analysis_iter_config.py#L110-L118

Should be 
```python
        return ret % (its, rets, fmt, cfs, self._address())
```

title: Minimal ResConfig via config dict fails with segfault
body:
While the following works:
```python
import os
from res.enkf import ResConfig, SiteConfig

def touch(filename):

        fh.write(" ")

def test_works(tmpdir):
    touch(tmpdir + "/rpfile")
    touch(tmpdir + "/datafile")

NUM_REALIZATIONS  1
RUNPATH_FILE rpfile
DATA_FILE datafile
LICENSE_PATH license
"""
        )

title: Missing datafile results in core dumped
body:
**Describe the bug**
The following results in a core dump:

```
from res.enkf import ResConfig

ResConfig("config.ert")
```
where config.ert contains:
```
JOBNAME  Job%d
NUM_REALIZATIONS  1
RUNPATH_FILE does_exist
DEFINE A B
DATA_KW A B
DATA_FILE does_not_exist
```
and the file `does_not_exist` does not exist.

The error occurrs because `ecl_util_get_num_cpu` does not check whether the file exists and tries to read from an invalid file handle.

title: Function step will only return one record
body:
**Describe the bug**
A bug on line 45 in the following file means that the output data from the function is passed as data to __one__ record. The intended functionality is that the function should return a dict with entries for each of the outputs, and then each of the entries in the dictionary should be uploaded as a separate record. 

https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/9cfb07b5d3020d3e6c88bffe5d7ec7058dadf9cd/ert_shared/ensemble_evaluator/entity/function_step.py#L30-L48

Line 45 should instead be:
```
        futures.append(_transmit(output, transmitter, function_output[output.get_name()]))
```

**Expected behavior**
Each output should have its own output uploaded as a separate unique record.

**Enviromment**
 - OS: All
 - ERT/Komodo Release: main
 - Python version: All
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: No (but also N/A)

title: Remove use of mutable class as default argument in builder
body:
We should not use mutable instances as default values to functions. 

https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/9cfb07b5d3020d3e6c88bffe5d7ec7058dadf9cd/ert_shared/ensemble_evaluator/ensemble/builder.py#L58

The following example illustrates the problem: 

```
class B:
    
    def __init__(self, a=1):
        self.a = a

def test(b= B()):
    b.a += 1
    return b
    
print(test().a)
print(test().a)
print(test().a)
```

This will print

```
2
3
4
```

The standard way to solve this problem is to let the default value in the function signature be `None`, and then in the constructor set the value to B() if the input parameter is `None`.

title: Flaky test for BaseService

title: Misc issues related to BaseService
body:
**Describe the bug**
There are some false assumptions in `test_base_service.py` and an opening for a race-condition in `_base_service.py`

Some tests in `test_base_service.py` assume the service is running, but depending on timing the service-process may have exited before test-code is run. Fix this by adding `time.sleep(10)` to service-code in relevant tests.

If a service-process finishes before the internal thread of BaseService starts up the code never enters the while loop here

https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/8041f0eb1bc2541b4a71464205205c359d7528a6/ert_shared/services/_base_service.py#L150-L152

and the method returns empty string, causing errors. Fix this by ensuring at least one iteration in the while-loop and treat an empty string similar to None (None shoould

**To Reproduce**
Add `e.g. time.sleep(2)`  first in run() method here to simulate slow thread start

https://github.com/equinor/ert/blob/8041f0eb1bc2541b4a71464205205c359d7528a6/ert_shared/services/_base_service.py#L103-L105

and remember `import time`

**Additional context**
This failure is likely to be caused by issues related to what's described above

https://github.com/equinor/ert/pull/2141/checks?check_run_id=3791762953#step:8:5348

title: NUM_CPU is not rendered correctly
body:
**Describe the bug**
`NUM_CPU` is not propagated correctly to forward model when set explicitly in ERT configuration file.

If I add `NUM_CPU 4` (or some other integer larger than 1) to an ERT configuration file (for instance the poly example) I would expect `<NUM_CPU>` to be templated as `4` during the forward model. Instead the user gets `1`. I have reproduced the error myself.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Have ERT installed (I used komodo stable)
2. Grab a fresh copy of the poly example
3. Add `NUM_CPU 4` to `poly.ert`
4. Add the following job description file `DUMP_NUM_CPU`
```
EXECUTABLE echo
ARGLIST <NUM_CPU>
```
5. Add the job to the forward model by prepending the following to lines to `poly.ert`:
```
INSTALL_JOB dump_num_cpu DUMP_NUM_CPU
FORWARD_MODEL dump_num_cpu
```
6. Run the config `ert ensemble_experiment poly.ert` 
7. Inspect the `dump_num_cpu.stdout.1` to see the value of `NUM_CPU`

**Expected behavior**
I expected the content of `dump_num_cpu.stdout.1` to be `4`, but it is `1`.

**Enviromment**
 - OS: RHEL7
 - ERT/Komodo Release: 2021.09.00
 - Python version: 3.6

**Additional context**
While resolving this error we should also ensure that `NUM_CPU` correctly overrides the value loaded from the data file. That is, if you extend the poly example even further by creating the file `POLY.DATA` with the content:

```
PARALLEL 8 /
```

and add `DATA_FILE POLY.DATA` to `poly.ert` (without the `NUM_CPU` keyword) I would expect `NUM_CPU` to render as `8` in the forward model. If I afterwards add `NUM_CPU 3` to `poly.ert` I would expect `NUM_CPU` to render to `3` in the forward model.

title: `Error message: state_map_iset__: illegal state transition for realization: x`
body:
**Summary of investigation after observing `Error message: state_map_iset__: illegal state transition for realization:91 16 -> 8` during `ensemble_experiment`:**

1) An `ert es_mda` run (`iter-{0,1,2,3}`) was successfully executed with 100 realizations, with some failed realizations (which is normal).
     - One of these failed realizations was realization 91, which did not successfully complete `iter-1` (failed during Eclipse simulation).

2) In a (prediction) `ert ensemble_experiment` following the `es_mda` run, realization 91 is expected to fail (since there is no `iter-3` to use as starting point for the realization).
    - What is unexpected behavior though is that when realization 91 (as expected) fail, this also crashes the ERT client with:
    ```
    Error message: state_map_iset__: illegal state transition for realisation:91 16 -> 8 

    See file: /tmp/ert_abort_dump.username.YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS.log for more details of the crash.
    Setting the environment variable "ERT_SHOW_BACKTRACE" will show the backtrace on stderr.
    Aborted (core dumped)
    ```
---

After some test runs, this appears to be related to ERT storage. When the `es_mda` run is finished, there have been automatically created "cases" called `default_{0,1,2,3}` in ERT storage. When the (prediction) `ensemble_experiment` is started afterwards (using same storage path in the configuration file), it looks like default chosen case by ERT is `default_3` (the last generated case by ERT in `es_mda`). Either deleting ERT storage between `es_mda` and the following `ensemble_experiment`, use different ERT storage paths in the two ERT config files, or alternatively create + use a new "case" different from `default_*` in the ERT GUI, removes the crash / error message.

---

**Conclusion with current information:**
* _Workaround for user:_ Delete ERT storage between `es_mda` and `ensemble_experiment`, use different ERT storage paths (i.e. value for `ENSPATH`) in the two ERT configuration files, or create a new ERT case in ERT GUI before (prediction) ensemble experiment.
* _Potential ERT bug fix:_ Do not by default reuse `default_*` from previous `es_mda`run when subsequently starting an ensemble experiment.

title: Locally executed FunctionStep may cause crashes on macOS
body:
**Describe the bug**
Background: https://bugs.python.org/issue33725

Since we use `multiprocessing`/`forkserver`, anything on the "child side" of the `fork()` call may cause `+initialize` methods of the macOS SDK to be called, which may crash the process(es).

For our own usage, we protect against this by accessing `_scproxy` in the `forkserver` via `set_forkserver_preload`. However, when arbitrary code execution is allowed, it is impossible to know up-front what `+initialize` calls are going to be made.

Generally, using `fork()` at all combined with `asyncio` is problematic, and strongly advised against by the python community https://bugs.python.org/issue21998#msg361755

Note: this affects only local execution, remote execution is not affected.

**To Reproduce**
Unknown at this time

**Expected behavior**
FunctionStep should just work, no matter what code is called

**Enviromment**
 - OS: macOS
 - ERT/Komodo Release: main@HEAD
 - Python version: 3.6+
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: no

**Additional context**
Human readable https://wefearchange.org/2018/11/forkmacos.rst.html

title: hypothesis and pytest fixtures
body:
**Describe the bug**

Using pytest's fixtures of scope function with hypothesis doesn't work (on purpose).

I would like to have some code that runs before and after EVERY test function.  My use case, which is probably not that outlandish, is to reset an in-memory database object.  Yes, I would like to use hypothesis with a database.  It wouldn't be great testing if tests succeeded or failed based on what already is in the database, so I would like to clear it between tests.

Pytest fixtures do the job, I've used them several times.  But with `hypothesis`, there's an issue: since my tests use the `given` decorator, it might make sense to have fixtures using an additional scope.  In my case, I don't want the database to reset every time the function is called... but I do want it to reset when every function ends.

**To Reproduce**

1. In a `conftest.py` file, some simple fixture:

    ```python
    import pytest

    @pytest.fixture
    def db():
        print("Before db.")
        yield
        print("After")
    ```

2. Write a simple test in a separate file.  In my case, it's `test_account` and it refers to an external model, but that's easy to emulate:

    ```python
    @given(account=st.builds(Account))
    def test_create(account, db):
        data = account.dict(exclude={"id"})
        created = account
        assert created.dict(exclude={"id"}) == data
    ```

When running `pytest`, I get the following error:

```
...
E                               hypothesis.errors.FailedHealthCheck: test/test_account.py::test_create uses the 'db' fixture, which is reset between function calls but not between test cases generated by `@given(...)`.  You can change it to a module- or session-scoped fixture if it is safe to reuse; if not we recommend using a context manager inside your test function.  See https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/how-to/fixtures.html#scope-sharing-fixtures-across-classes-modules-packages-or-session for details on fixture scope.                                                                   
E                               See https://hypothesis.readthedocs.io/en/latest/healthchecks.html for more information about this. If you want to disable just this health check, add HealthCheck.function_scoped_fixture to the suppress_health_check settings for this test.
```

So yeah, the error is verbose, there's a URL, but I couldn't get this fixture to work.  I tried to remove the `yield` keyword, to make it a normal function and add the finalizer to the request: no dice.  I actually tried to have this fixture do nothing and return something right away, no dice either, the error persists.  The documentation doesn't mention context manager (at least, I don't see it), so perhaps I'm missing something obvious.

So the first question is: why not?  The concept of scope, in particular function scopes, may be a little counter-intuitive when using `@given`, but then, it doesn't seem to cancel out the initial intent.  Obviously, having a scope of `module` or `session` doesn't solve my issue, since this fixture will run only once (per module, or per session test), which is not what I want.

**Expected behavior**

Considering the error is complete and explicit, I'd say this is the intended result.  What would be the best way to address my issue without breaking anything?

**Enviromment**
 - OS: win10 (64-bit)
 - Python version: 3.9

Thanks for this great tool!

title: Confusing error message on missing observation files
body:
**Describe the bug**
If observation related files are missing an error message related to changes in interpretation of observation paths in ERT 2.3 are displayed. **To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

2. Open the poly example (`cd test-data/local/poly_example`)

(ert-env39) markus$ rm poly_obs_data.txt 
(ert-env39) markus$ ert test_run poly.ert 
**********************************************************************
* In ert version 2.3 we have changed how filepaths are interpreted   *

title: SharedDiskRecordTransmitter assumes JSON for numerical records
body:
**Describe the bug**
The e.g. `dump` method of the transmitter allows the MIME to vary, but the file on disk is JSON and `dump`'s implementation is basically a copy operation. So even though you call `dump(r, "text/csv")` you'll get JSON.

Storing the file on disk is supposed to be an implementation detail, so JSON on disk isn't the problem in itself.

title: Restarting ES_MDA from an iteration causes a crash
body:
**Describe the bug**
When you attempt to restart ESMDA from an iteration it will crash with the following error message:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/prog/res/komodo/2021.08.rc0-py36-rhel7/root/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/ert_gui/model/progress_proxy.py", line 99, in _source_data_changed
    if top_left.internalPointer().type != NodeType.ITER:
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'type'
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. `ert gui poly.ert'
2. Run ESMDA using standard settings, and wait for it to complete
3. Restart ESMDA from `default_2` according to the description here: https://ert.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/gui/gui.html#restarting-es-mda
4. After clicking start ERT will crash and the error message above will appear. 



**Expected behavior**
No crash

**Enviromment**
 - OS: RHEL7
 - ERT/Komodo Release: 2021.08.rc0-py36
 - Python version: 3.6
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: no

title: Inconsistent status messages from CLI
body:
**Describe the bug**
Ert displays the followings status 

```
    ■ Waiting         0/194
    ■ Pending         0/194
    ■ Running         0/194
    ■ Failed          2/194
    ■ Finished      192/194
    ■ Unknown         0/194
Simulations completed.
2 jobs failed due to the error: Process exited with status code 1
135 jobs failed due to the error: The run is cancelled due to reaching MAX_RUNTIME
```
While the number of failing jobs is correct, the number of jobs reported to be killed by MAX_RUNTIME is way too high, and conflicts with the number of finished jobs reported by ert. 

**To Reproduce**
Not able to reproduce the error at this point.

**Expected behavior**
Status messages from ert should be consistent and not conflict with each other. 

**Enviromment**
 - OS: RHEL7
 - ERT/Komodo Release: 2021.07
 - Python version: 3.6
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: yes

**Additional context**
Originally reported by user on Slack

title: Bug in argument parsing for forward model jobs
body:
**Describe the bug**
Odd number of ' escaped by " " triggers an error message. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

**Expected behavior**
Use of ' escaped by " " should be allowed, and not trigger a error message. 


**Enviromment**
 - OS: RHEL7
 - ERT/Komodo Release: 2021.07.00
 - Python version: 3.6
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: No (but unrelated)

**Additional context**
Originally reported by user on slack

title: Job status not updated for LSF when using the ensemble evaluator
body: **Describe the bug** While testing #1863 I realised that running a bleeding ERT on an LSF cluster with the ensemble evaluator enabled is not giving any updates to the job statuses. Instead, they all remain pending while there is clear progress on disk and in the end even the queue system reports it as completed. **To Reproduce [using LSF]** Steps to reproduce the behavior towards LSF: 1. Open an RGS node 2. Source komodo/bleeding 3. Get a fresh copy of the poly_example 4. Change `QUEUE_SYSTEM` from `LOCAL` to `LSF` 5. Run `ert gui poly.ert --enable-ensemble-evaluator` 6. Run an ensemble experiment and observe that none of the job statuses are changing in the detailed view **Expected behavior** I expected the job statuses to update and at the end of the run both the jobs and the entire realisation to be labelled green in the details status window. **Screenshots** **Enviromment** - OS: On-premise - ERT/Komodo Release: bleeding - Python version: 3.6 - Remote/HPC execution involved: yes

title: We are trying to communicate over the wrong port range
body:
**Describe the bug**
I discovered while doing some internal testing that in our bleeding builds ERT is using the wrong port range and hence failing to communicate back statuses from the compute nodes to the client. Afterwards I reproduced the problem on `main` running the polynomial example on my laptop.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Pick up a fresh installation of ERT
2. Head over to the poly example `test-data/local/poly-example`
3. Run an ensemble evaluation using `ert ensemble_experiment poly.ert --enable-ensemble-evaluator`
4. Run `grep "dispatch_url" poly_out/real_0/iter_0/jobs.json` and observe the port used

**Expected behavior**
The port range expected to be used is `51820 - 51840`. In addition, a similar setup should be attempted to run on an RGS node, but with the `QUEUE_SYSTEM LSF` instead of `QUEUE_SYSTEM LOCAL` to ensure that we are back into a functioning state on-premise.

**Enviromment**
 - OS: Equinor RHEL7 and MacOS
 - ERT/Komodo Release: `main`
 - Python version: 3.6 on-premise, 3.9 on MacOS.
 - Remote/HPC execution involved: it was first discovered on lsf, should be tested again after fixed on lsf, but the cause of the issue can be reproduced locally without an HPC cluster.

title: HISTORY_OBSERVATION does not load the last entry in the summary vector
body:
**Describe the bug**
When loading SUMMARY_OBSERVATIONS the last data point in the summary vector is not loaded, and becomes `nan`.
The responses are loaded for the last time step, indicating that this is not an intended feature.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
Add this to: `tests/data/test_integration_data.py`
```python
@pytest.mark.usefixtures("copy_snake_oil")
def test_summary_collector():
    res_config = ResConfig("snake_oil.ert")
    ert = EnKFMain(res_config)
    summary = EclSum("refcase/SNAKE_OIL_FIELD.UNSMRY")
    data = SummaryObservationCollector.loadObservationData(ert, "default_0")

    assert (
        data["FOPR"].values.tolist()
        == summary.numpy_vector("FOPRH", report_only=True).tolist()
    )
```

**Expected behavior**
Expect that test to pass and that the internal `ert` data is the same as the refcase summary vector.

title: Monitor produces unexpected ordering of events
body:
**Describe the bug**
In a test, step- and job-level dispatch events are sent rapidly to the ensemble evaluator. The monitor yields the following:

1. snapshot
2. ensemble start
3. ensemble stopped

**To Reproduce**
1. `git checkout equinor/consumer-driven-contracts`
2. `pytest tests/ensemble_evaluator/test_ensemble_evaluator.py::test_ensemble_monitor_communication_given_failing_job`

**Expected behavior**
Per Postel's law the evaluator should accept poorly ordered events from the dispatcher, though that's not what's happening here—but the evaluator should be conservative in what it sends.

This isn't possible, now, since the step and job level events pass through it via multiple separate streams.

title: Ensemble evaluator using same port as ert-storage
body:
When ert is launching ert-storage, it is binding a socket, by default, on 127.0.0.1 starting on port 51820. The ee is trying to bind a socket on the servers public ip address using the same port range. As they are not bound on the same ip, it fails to detect them as open. 

A solution is to bind on  0.0.0.0, thus ensuring that it is discoverable on both local and public addresses.

title: Race condition in calculating the progress for the evaluator tracker
body:
**Describe the bug**
Especially after #1597, though still probably possible before, we defer calculation of progress for `SnapshotUpdateEvent` till after some time (1-15 seconds) by batching all events inside that time frame. There exist a race condition where we want to calculate the progress for phase 0 and some `SnapshotUpdateEvent` generated in phase 0, but the phase has since changed to 1 by e.g. the `EnsembleSmoother`. This way, you'll get a wrong calculation of progress.

**To Reproduce**
Run the ensemble smoother with the legacy evaluator.

**Expected behavior**
Progress should be correctly calculated

title: Total progress calculation is wrong when using ensemble evaluator
body: Progress from finished realisation is not counted in the progress bar.

body:

**Expected behavior**
Cancelling should be immediate.

title: Evaluator should handle disconnected dispatchers
body:
**Describe the bug**
We store dispatchers as `websocket` instances in a list. If, in some `recv()` call on a dispatcher, a connection-related exception is thrown, ERT will run forever, unless the dispatcher reconnects (we have no broker, so the events might be gone).

**Expected behavior**
After some time, the step for which the missing dispatcher belongs, must be set to failed with a message explaining why.

title: GUI lags for larger experiments
body:
**Describe the bug**
Seems the raw flow of events from the dispatchers is too much for the GUI to handle for the moment. All dispatcher events will produce a snapshot update event, which then will be handled by the GUI.

It's not necessary to update the GUI so often. The CLI will also be spammed, since it basically `print` on ever update event.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Make 100 poly_eval.py jobs
1. Set MAX_RUNNING to 1
1. `ert gui my_config.ert`
1. Run ensemble experiment (a couple of reals is fine)

**Expected behavior**
It's slow, and if you look at `status.json`, the reals will be done long before they are done in the GUI.

title: Improve documentation of the FIELD keyword
body:
**Improve documentation of FIELD keyword**
A common user error is to specify an ID for the FIELD keyword that does not match the input file. Even for the option where PARAMETER is used it is a requirement that the ID for FIELD is identical to the keyword for the property in the GRDECL file or the ROFF file. In particular when reading the ROFF file format, the mismatch results in error message not indicating what is actually wrong. When using APSGUI from RMS, the file has property name (keyword in the ROFF file) with the same name as the ROFF filename (except for the .roff suffix).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Try to read ROFF file created by APSGUI plugin in RMS but specify a wrong ID name.

**Expected behavior**
An error message to the user telling the user that there is a mismatch between the user specified ID for FIELD and the name of the property in the input file when the input file format is ROFF binary format.

**Error message example:**
>> ert gui trestakk_hist_aps.ert
Using RANDOM_SEED: 50312
CRITICAL: 23/04 - 18:27:02  Using RANDOM_SEED: 50312
Error while handling error. Exiting. File: ../../../lib/rms/rms_tag.cpp Function: rms_tag_fread_header, Line: 90
Error message: rms_tag_fread_header: not at tag - header aborting
Error while handling error. Exiting. File: ../../../lib/rms/rms_tag.cpp Function: rms_tag_fread_header, Line: 90
Error message: rms_tag_fread_header: not at tag - header aborting

title: Allow spaces and commas in argument list when escaped by "
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Usage of spaces and commas in arguments to forward model jobs is very limiting and un-intuitive. With spaces an error is reported, but for a comma-separated argument list only the first elem is picked and the rest is ignored without any warning.  These limitations are making it hard to utilize many great argparse features, and seems to be forcing a script-specific config file.

This is an example of something that will give an error: 
```
FORWARD_MODEL poly_eval(<ARG0>=3, <ARG1>="something hei")
```

Where `POLY_EVAL` has been modified to 
```
EXECUTABLE poly_eval.py

ARGLIST <ARG0> <ARG1>
```
The following will not fail, but everything after the second comma will be ignored.

```
FORWARD_MODEL poly_eval(<ARG0>=3, <ARG1>="something,hei")
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Spaces and commas inside " should be considered escaped.

**Additional context**
The reason why this happens is because libres will first split the arg string on comma, ignoring the fact that these might be inside "".  (See: https://github.com/equinor/libres/blob/a2a0f202aa8c733ee48e918ac887cd1e530e6760/lib/res_util/subst_list.cpp#L795)

It then searches for = inside each part of the split string. If no = is found inside a part, it's just silently ignored. 

Spaces are actively disallowed here: https://github.com/equinor/libres/blob/a2a0f202aa8c733ee48e918ac887cd1e530e6760/lib/res_util/subst_list.cpp#L832:L836

One possible solution to the comma problem is to make the split string function aware of " and ', and do the right thing :tm:. For the space problem we could disable the space checking and error reporting. However, both these solution touches core parts of the libres parsing and substitution and can/will have unintended side effects.

title: Parsing of num_cpu from data file is buggy
body:
The parsing of the number of processors needed from the data file seems to be buggy: 
https://github.com/equinor/ecl/blob/007f000ba97b04b670217aa425220f907c022e79/lib/ecl/ecl_util.cpp#L1294:L1309

In particular, if the word parallel is used elsewhere in the file it seems to fail. 
```
----------------------------------------------------------------------
-- A very simple test case for the shared memory parallel option.
-- --------------------------------------------------------------
```
Failing case can be found here: `/prog/res/ecl/grid/2020.2/eclipse/data/PARALLEL.DATA`

title: Spurious dataChanged events emitted by the Snapshot Model
body:
(This is only applicable after #566)

**Describe the bug**
As the EnsembleEvaluator, even though I send an update about a job's memory usage, the entire job list GUI has to be re-rendered, because `dataChanged` is emitted without checking if something actually changed.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
Write a test where you inspect `dataChanged` for the qt `SnapshotModel`
In that test, you send a partial snapshot event with `"current_memory_usage"` as the only data point

**Expected behavior**
_One_ `dataChanged` is emitted from the model

**Actual behaviour**
All nodes in the job's parents are yielding a `dataChanged` event

title: Add pyrsistent as dependency
body:
a7a5263dca9c00e30c1434a320998b7bdb2c1e24 introduced `pyrsistent` as a dependency of `ert` without adding it to the `setup.py` list. This should be fixed.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3437958/106103700-a2618280-6141-11eb-875b-f63d427a9f87.png)

**To Reproduce**

[ert_debug.tar.gz](https://github.com/equinor/ert/files/5885465/ert_debug.tar.gz)

It should not matter to ERT whether the START keyword is set or not, this should be left to the simulator.

 - Remote/HPC execution involved: Affects both local and remote execution

Reported by user on Slack

title: ERT Storage fails when data is NaN
body:
Some responses contain NaN in their values. Starlette's JSON encoder explicitly disallows this, thus causing a 500 Server Error.

https://github.com/encode/starlette/blob/e4307065ea6dbe708fba9643d14fe7adfff06d46/starlette/responses.py#L164

title: Update GENERAL_OBSERVATION error message
body:
When there are problems finding a observation file when using `GENERAL_OBSERVATION`, this error message is shown:
```
**********************************************************************
* In ert version 2.3 we have changed how filepaths are interpreted   *
* in the observation file. When using the keywords OBS_FILE,         *
* ERROR_COVAR and INDEX_FILE in the category GENERAL_OBSERVATION     *
* the filenames will be interpreted relative to the main observation *
* file.                                                              *
*                                                                    *
* Please update the OBS_FILE, ERROR_COVAR and INDEX_FILE keywords    *
* by removing the path to the main observation file.                 *
**********************************************************************
```

ERT 2.3 is really old, so this error message should be updated to a more general error message about not being able to find the observation file. 

*Expected behaviour:*
I would expect an error message stating something along the lines of The configured OBS_FILE "poly_obs_data.txt" is missing.

*To reproduce:*
This can be reproduced by changing  `OBS_FILE   = poly_obs_data.txt;` to a file that does not exist in the `observations` file in the poly example folder.

```

    self.updateDetailedProgress()
  File "/prog/res/komodo/2020.07.rc1-py36/root/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ert_shared/models/base_run_model.py", line 23, in dispatch
    return method( self, *args , **kwargs)
  File "/prog/res/komodo/2020.07.rc1-py36/root/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ert_shared/models/base_run_model.py", line 255, in updateDetailedProgress
    self.update_progress_for_index(iteration, idx, run_arg)
  File "/prog/res/komodo/2020.07.rc1-py36/root/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ert_shared/models/base_run_model.py", line 234, in update_progress_for_index
    fms = ForwardModelStatus.load(run_arg.runpath, num_retry=1)
  File "/prog/res/komodo/2020.07.rc1-py36/root/lib/python3.6/site-packages/res/job_queue/forward_model_status.py", line 135, in load
    status = cls.try_load(path)
  File "/prog/res/komodo/2020.07.rc1-py36/root/lib/python3.6/site-packages/res/job_queue/forward_model_status.py", line 124, in try_load
    status.add_job(ForwardModelJobStatus.load(job, state, path))
  File "/prog/res/komodo/2020.07.rc1-py36/root/lib/python3.6/site-packages/res/job_queue/forward_model_status.py", line 65, in load
    end_time = _deserialize_date(data["end_time"])
KeyError: 'end_time'
```

We should catch the exception and

1. inform the user that we failed to read a file on **disk** (pointing to potential disk issues, which is common)
1. tell the user **what** file we failed to read, so that the user can take a look at this file. Maybe the user is proficient and sees that the file is valid JSON. Disk issues then become a likely suspect.
1. show the exception—maybe the JSON indeed is bad (like in the case of poorly serialized data)

title: Logarithmic distribution: support for negative standard deviation?
body:
This is more of a discussion placeholder. Currently all the log distributions convert standard deviation to positive number by using absolute value given in the priors file, eg.
```
LOG_PARAM LOGNORMAL 1 -10
```
would compute distribution as `exp(x * 10 + 1)==(e^1, e^11)` instead of  `exp(-x * 10 + 1)==(e^(-9), e^1)`, which yields quite different results. Shall we provide support for such small distributions too? 

Maybe this is not too much relevant for the reservoir domain but some other applications.

title: Cursor jumping when changing weights
body:
**Current behaviour**
When I try to change the weight of the first iteration when running es mda, the cursor moves to the end of the line after each added character. This is really odd behaviour.

**Wanted behaviour**
When I type, the cursor should stay put, not jump to end of line. In other words, it should be possible to add the weight `12, ` to the front of the weight line without odd cursor movement.

**How to replicate**
Open poly case and select `ES MDA`. Put your cursor at the front of the `Relative weights` field and try to add a weight, i.e. changing the default `4, 2, 1` to `8, 4, 2, 1`.

title: Detailed progress is broken for Python 3

milestone.title: Testing version of ERT with Python 3

body: The detailed progress window in the GUI seems to be broken for Python 3 on the RGS machines. It collapses into one of the sides.

title: ExportModel.exportField not working
body: The `ExportModel` `exportField` method will not work as one of the called functions does not exist: https://github.com/equinor/libres/blob/f3fdee66b1facc5fe6f6e820e2872c8f4bff8fde/python/res/enkf/config/enkf_config_node.py#L136

title: STOP_LONG_RUNNING stopped working
body:
Users report that after the queue system refactoring the `STOP_LONG_RUNNING` keywords has stopped working.

We should start by reproducing the issue in the poly case.

title: MAX_RUNTIME not working?
body: Users have reported `MAX_RUNTIME` to not work properly over `lsf`. I suggest to modify the poly case so that the job sleeps for a long time, add `MAX_RUNTIME 2` and see whether we can reproduce.

title: Util abort when closing ERT
body:
To reproduce:
- source /prog/res/komodo/2019.12.rc2
- ert gui poly.ert
- run single realization test run 
- wait til finished
- click create plots from run-dialog
- close plot
- close run-dialog
- close ert

title: Esc closes run_dialog with no message
body:
As a user I do not want the monitoring dialog (`run_dialog.py`) to close immediately when the `Esc` key is pressed (possibly inadvertently), so that I can check what is the status of the case I am running

The dialog disappears, it seems that simulations keeps running, but it's unclear whether new ones will be submitted or not. Pressing again `Run simulations` bring up a new dialog partially filled, but I suspect new simulations are also submitted.
Pressing, eg, `Create plot` after closing the dialog with `Esc` causes ERT to crash.

I suspect the best solution would be to just avoid closing the dialog.
@ManInFez recently added some cose to handle a `QCloseEvent` but that does not seem to work properly, at least on my machine (OSX, Python27, Qt5)

title: Analysis module when running ies is not available

milestone.title: Testing version of ERT with Python 3

body: When iterable is choosen when retrieving list of available analysis modules - no one is retrieved which is causing a exception further down the line. Not sure why it works in python2, but we should make sure it's also works as intended in py2 and not just works by chance.

title: Torque driver unable to get job status
body:
Running Ert (cli) on the Azure cluster using the torque driver
Right after starting, a message like this is spit out for every job:```** Warning: failed to get job status for job:218 from file:/tmp/enkf-qstat-5956-365084```  
I do have write access to the `/tmp` folder, but the file is not created (regular users might have write access to that folder, but that's another issue).

The jobs actually are started and complete correctly, but Ert hangs, most likely because it's unable to detect that the jobs are completed

title: Ert gui load results manually issue
body:
Opening the `Load results manually` dialogue within the ert gui will immediately result in a crash:

```
ASSERT failure in QAbstractItemView::setModel: "A model should return the exact same index (including its internal id/pointer) when asked for it twice in a row.", file itemviews/qabstractitemview.cpp, line 667

Error message: Program received signal:6

See file: /tmp/ert_abort_dump.lpha.20190606-095449.log for more details of the crash.
Setting the environment variable "ERT_SHOW_BACKTRACE" will show the backtrace on stderr.2
Aborted (core dumped)
```
The issue becomes apparent  when PyQt4 is upgraded from 4.11 to 4.12. (perhaps they made the new version stricter)

The problem occurs when the `createIndex` from `QAbstractItemModel` which is inherited for the `AllCasesModel`. In the call the `parent` is forwarded which seems to be an issue. To be honest I am not completely sure how this should be handled either.

When leaving the parent to default, the dialogue window opens correctly. ~~However when the load button is used all loading of data fails. Exactly how those two are related I'm a bit unsure of. The `load` in `LoadResultsPanel` only uses the qt components to get the casename, iterations and realizations. Why those fail further down the line (and not failing when using pyqt 4.11), is unclear.~~
I got fooled by the default value of `iteration` when using the `Load results manually` dialogue, and tried to load an iteration that didn't existed..

title: Wrong information in status.json when using target files
body:
Jobs are labeled as a success in `status.json` if they do not produce their target file. Which obviously is wrong.

To reproduce, make replace the content of `POLY_EVAL` with:
```
EXECUTABLE poly_eval.py
TARGET_FILE my_target_file
```

and run `poly.ert`. Now, `POLY_EVAL` should produce a file called `my_target_file` to be considered correct. _ERT_ does in the end conclude that it failed, but the `status.json` and hence the progress window displays misleading information. In addition, the forward model continues after a job has failed...
